1.title: Believer: Author David Axelrod
1.plot: David Axelrod, the mastermind of President Barack Obama's historic election campaigns, and their breakthrough use of technology, talks about his years as a journalist, political consultant, and ultimately senior adviser to the president.

2.title: Formula E Racing CEO Alejandro Agag
2.plot: Formula E is a Formula One-style professional championship using the world's first fully electric racing cars. The inaugural season in 2014-15 competed in the heart of nine major cities from Beijing to London. CEO Alejandro Agag explains.

3.title: Becoming Steve Jobs
3.plot: Authors Brent Schlender and Rick Tetzeli go inside their book "Becoming Steve Jobs," which takes on - and breaks down - many myths and stereotypes about the legendary executive. Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar moderates.

4.title: Medium's Ev Williams and Steven Levy
4.plot: We continue our track on the Future of News as John Hollar, a former journalist himself, sits down for an in-depth conversation with Medium's CEO Evan Williams, and the editor-in-chief of its tech hub Backchannel, Steven Levy.

5.title: KQED's John Boland & NPR's Jarl Mohn on the Future of News
5.plot: A new Revolutionaries track, "Re/New: The Future of News," examines how technology is changing everything about the news and journalism. NPR CEO Jarl Mohn and KQED CEO John Boland explore the public media view in this kickoff episode.

6.title: The Thrilling Adventures of Lovelace and Babbage
6.plot: Victorian London's most dynamic duo: Charles Babbage, the unrealized inventor of the computer, and his muse, Ada, Countess of Lovelace, debut in a graphic novel of adventure and humor. Author Sydney Padua explains to host Ryan Germick.

7.title: MIT's Cynthia Breazeal & Microsoft Research's Eric Horvitz with the BBC's Rory Cellan-Jones
7.plot: Two AI pioneers explore how machine intelligence may remake our world. Eric Horvitz, managing director of Microsoft Research, and MIT's Cynthia Breazeal, chief scientist of the Robotics firm Jibo, join the BBC's Rory Cellan-Jones.

8.title: SuperBetter with Jane McGonigal and Laura Sydell
8.plot: Jane McGonigal returns to Revolutionaries with "SuperBetter: A Revolutionary Approach to Getting Stronger, Happier, Braver and More Resilient," in which she applies the psychology of games to life's challenges. NPR's Laura Sydell moderates.

9.title: Composer and Cellist Philip Sheppard
9.plot: Philip Sheppard is acclaimed as a composer, conductor, arranger, and innovative performer. His work combines digital and traditional instrumentation to reinvent perceptions of classical music. Will Travis moderates - and listens.

10.title: Machines of Loving Grace with Author John Markoff
10.plot: Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist John Markoff examines the future of machine learning. The result is an incisive and chilling look at our lives today - and what may come tomorrow. Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar moderates.

11.title: How We Got to Now with Steven Johnson
11.plot: Bestselling author Steven Johnson explores six topics - glass, cold, sound, clean, time, and light - and explains how related, unexpected discoveries in each led to our modern life. Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar moderates.

12.title: An Evening with the US Digital Services Team
12.plot: The U.S. Digital Service is quietly rethinking - and remaking - the way the federal government harnesses digital technology to serve the nation. Key USDS team members explain to Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar.

1.title: The Facebook Effect
1.plot: Facebook founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg and author David Kirkpatrick in conversation with NPR's Guy Raz.

2.title: Reality is Broken: Why Games Make Us Better and How They Can Change the World
2.plot: Author Dr. Jane McGonigal in conversation with NPR's Laura Sydell.

3.title: Steve Jobs: The Authorized Biography
3.plot: Author Walter Isaacson discusses his major biography of Steve Jobs with Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar.

4.title: An IBM Centennial Lecture
4.plot: Samuel J. Palmisano, Chairman of the Board, President and Chief Executive Officer of IBM, speaks about the importance and meaning of IBM's centennial as a corporation, immediately followed by a conversation with Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar.

5.title: The Technology of Animation
5.plot: Dreamworks Animation CEO Jeffrey Katzenberg and Chief Technology Officer Ed Leonard in conversation with Vice President and Chief Technology Officer for HP's Personal Systems Group, Philip McKinney.

6.title: A Computer Called Watson
6.plot: IBM's Dr. David Ferrucci, IBM Fellow and Principal Investigator of the Watson/Jeopardy. project, in conversation with journalist Richard Waters of the Financial Times.

7.title: Idea Man
7.plot: Author Paul Allen, co-founder of Microsoft, in conversation about his autobiography "Idea Man" with Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Jose Antonio Vargas.

8.title: The Man Who Invented the Computer, John Vincent Atanasoff
8.plot: Pulitzer Prize-winning author Jane Smiley in conversation with Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar.

9.title: In the Plex: How Google Thinks, Works and Shapes Our Lives
9.plot: Author and journalist discusses his wide-ranging profile of Google with NPR's Laura Sydell.

10.title: Maurice Wilkes: The Man and His Machine
10.plot: Dr. David Hartley of the University of Cambridge remembers the life and achievements of the inventor of the early EDSAC computer, Sir Maurice Wilkes, with Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar.

11.title: Worm: The First Digital War
11.plot: Author Mark Bowden and Microsoft's T.J. Campana, senior program manager of the company's Digital Crimes Unit, discuss cyber warfare with John Markoff of The New York Times.

12.title: The Startup Game
12.plot: Author and venture capital pioneer Bill Draper in conversation with KQED's Dave Iverson.

13.title: The Challenge and Promise of Artificial Intelligence
13.plot: Google Research Director Peter Norvig and Microsoft Distinguished Engineer Eric Horvitz discuss the promise and challenges of artificial intelligence with KQED's Tim Olson.

1.title: An Evening with Marissa Mayer
1.plot: Silicon Valley executive Marissa Mayer discusses her life, background and meteoric career at Google with NPR's Laura Sydell in an interview recorded just months before Mayer was named CEO of Yahoo!.

2.title: Driving Innovation: Detroit Comes to Silicon Valley
2.plot: Bill Ford, Chairman of Ford Motor Company and the great-grandson of company founder Henry Ford, discusses the future of automobiles and the importance of new technology with Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar.

3.title: Turing's Cathedral
3.plot: Author George Dyson discusses his sweeping biography of computer pioneer John von Neumann and the early history of electronic computing with Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar.

4.title: The Art & Technology Behind the Google Doodles
4.plot: The team behind the Google Doodles, which appear on the home search page for Google every day, discuss the philosophy and technology behind the doodles with Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar.

5.title: Doing Well by Doing Good
5.plot: John Wood, former Microsoft executive and founder of the non-profit Room to Read, and Kiva CEO Matt Flannery discuss their transitions from private industry to philanthropy with KQED's Dave Iverson.

6.title: The Idea Factory: Bell Labs and the Great Age of American Innovation
6.plot: Author Jon Gertner discusses his wide-ranging exploration of Bell Labs and its role in the development of American technology with KQED's Dave Iverson.

7.title: Transforming Music: From Guitar Hero to Robotic Opera & Beyond
7.plot: MIT Media Lab Professor Tod Machover discusses his creative synthesis of technology and music, and previews his new robotic opera, in an interview with Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar.

8.title: In Conversation with Google's Eric Schmidt
8.plot: Google Executive Chairman Eric Schmidt discusses his leadership of the company and the growth of Google's influence and reach with Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar.

9.title: In Conversation with DARPA's Dan Kaufman
9.plot: Dan Kaufman, director of the Information Innovation Office of the Pentagon's high-tech DARPA agency, discusses the future of technology in defense and warfare with John Markoff of The New York Times.

10.title: Microsoft Research's Rick Rashid
10.plot: Rick Rashid, director of the Microsoft Research advanced technology lab in Silicon Valley, discusses the lab's current research work - with a focus on artificial intelligence - with John Markoff of The New York Times.

11.title: The Anthropology of Innovation
11.plot: Financial Times correspondent Gillian Tett discusses the interplay between anthropology and innovation with Intel Fellow Genevieve Bell, Stanford D-School executive director George Kembel, and UC Berkeley Professor Laura D'Andrea Tyson.

12.title: An Evening with Elon Musk
12.plot: Elon Musk discusses his vision for electric automobiles and his career as an entrepreneur with journalist Alison van Diggelen.

13.title: Game Changer Mark Cerny
13.plot: Legendary game developer and executive Mark Cerny discusses the current state and future of gaming with EA Chief Creative Officer Rich Hilleman.

14.title: In Conversation with Gavin Newsom
14.plot: California Lt Governor Gavin Newsom, a leader in the use of technology to deliver public services while Mayor of San Francisco, discusses his future vision of high-tech government with KQED's Michael Krasny.

1.title: Technology Under Sail: The America's Cup Comes to San Francisco
1.plot: Members of Team Oracle, holders of the America's Cup, go inside their title defense with the world's most sophisticated sailboats and are joined by Stan Honey, who produces breakthrough media coverage for the competition.

2.title: Lean In: Women, Work and the Will to Lead
2.plot: Sheryl Sandberg, author of the best-selling book "Lean In," talks about her professional career at Google and Facebook with friend and former boss Eric Schmidt, Executive Chairman of Google.

3.title: Chroniclers of Technology: An Evening with David Kirkpatrick, Steven Levy and John Markoff
3.plot: Three landmark journalists from the technology industry - David Kirkpatrick of Techonomy, Steven Levy of Wired and John Markoff of The New York Times - draw insights from their careers and discuss the state of tech today.

4.title: The Age of Edison: Electric Light and the Invention of Modern America
4.plot: Historian Ernest Freeberg, author of "The Age of Edison," explores the genius of the innovator and educator Thomas Edison with Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar.

5.title: An Evening with IBM Research's John Kelly
5.plot: IBM senior vice president and director of research Dr. John E. Kelly III chronicles impressive milestones in the company's history. Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar moderates the conversation.

6.title: An Evening with Intel's Justin Rattner
6.plot: Intel Senior Fellow Justin Rattner is an expert in global research, programming, security and user experience. Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar talks with him about everything from inspiration to working with Stephen Hawking.

7.title: An Evening with John P. Holdren
7.plot: Dr. John P. Holdren, director of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy, advises the President on issues like climate change, education and national security. John Markoff of The New York Times moderates.

8.title: Trip Hawkins, Game Changer
8.plot: Electronic Arts founder and interactive gaming pioneer Trip Hawkins has inspired change in the video game industry for decades. John Markoff of The New York Times moderates a conversation with this revolutionary.

9.title: An Evening with Qualcomm's Paul E. Jacobs
9.plot: Smartphones, laptops and tablets make mobile connection a way of life. Dr. Paul E. Jacobs, chairman of the board and CEO of Qualcomm, a leading mobile technology company, is in conversation with Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar.

10.title: Regis McKenna: Marketing Mastermind
10.plot: For decades Regis McKenna has helped turn fledgling companies into globally-recognized brands - from Intel's first microprocessor to Apple's original personal computer. John Markoff of The New York Times moderates.

11.title: Innovating the Future: SRI
11.plot: SRI International is one of the largest research and innovation centers in the world. John Markoff discusses research and innovation with SRI President and CEO Curt Carlson and VP of Information and Computing Science William Mark.

12.title: Padmasree Warrior with Laura Sydell
12.plot: Padmasree Warrior was one of Forbes's "100 Most Powerful Women" for two years running. The Cisco chief technology and strategy officer has blazed trails within the tech industry for more than 20 years. NPR's Laura Sydell moderates.

1.title: The New Digital Age: Authors Eric Schmidt and Jared Cohen in Conversation with Facebook's Sheryl Sandberg
1.plot: Google Chairman Eric Schmidt and Jared Cohen, Director of Google Ideas, in conversation with Sheryl Sandberg, Chief Operating Officer of Facebook, about the promise and perils of the digital revolution.

2.title: Technion's President Peretz Levie
2.plot: Peretz Lavie, president of Israel's leading technology university, the Technion, discusses the challenges and opportunities of global technology and his career as an academician and leader.

3.title: Creativity Inc. Author Ed Catmull
3.plot: Pixar Animation Studios CEO Ed Catmull explores his philosophy of managing a creative, technology-driven enterprise, and his long friendship with Steve Jobs, with Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar.

4.title: Game Changer Shuhei Yoshida
4.plot: A conversation with Shuhei Yoshida, President of Worldwide Studios at Sony Computer Entertainment, and Mark Cerny, video game industry hall of famer, on the evolution of gaming software and hardware.

6.title: An Evening with Arati Prabhakar
6.plot: Arati Prabhakar, director of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), joins John Markoff of The New York Times for a conversation about DARPA's history, impact, and new breakthroughs in technology and science.

7.title: MLB Advanced Media Founder Bob Bowman
7.plot: Bob Bowman, President and CEO of MLB Advanced Media, discusses how left Wall Street for a fledgling sports media startup into a streaming and production powerhouse worth $6 billion.

8.title: Akamai Co-Founder Tom Leighton
8.plot: Tom Leighton is co-founder of Akamai, one of the internet's most important companies. He discusses his distinguished career at Akamai and MIT, and reveals how the company came of age on 9/11.

9.title: The Innovators with Walter Isaacson
9.plot: Author Walter Isaacson discusses his new book "The Innovators: How a Group of Hackers, Geniuses and Geeks Created the Digital Revolution" with moderator John Hollar, CEO of the Computer History Museum.

10.title: Entrepreneur and Philanthropist Steve Case
10.plot: Revolutionaries goes on the road with a first stop at NPR's corporate headquarters in Washington, DC, with guest Steve Case, founder of AOL turned "Rise of the Rest" entrepreneur and philanthropist.

11.title: IBM Chairman and CEO Ginni Rometty
11.plot: In IBM's 103-year history providing leading-edge technology, it has had only nine chief executives - and only one woman CEO. Ginny Rometty discusses the company's history and future with Computer History Museum CEO John Hollar.

12.title: Defy Ventures Founder & CEO Catherine Hoke
12.plot: Defy Ventures coaches convicted felons in entrepreneurship and business. It has proved that former drug dealers and gang leaders can become successful. NPR's Laura Sydell moderates a conversation with Defy's founder, Catherine Hoke.

13.title: Theranos Founder Elizabeth Holmes
13.plot: Two years before the collapse of Theranos, controversial founder and CEO Elizabeth Holmes sat with KQED's Michael Krasny to discuss her vision for the purpose and future of the company.

14.title: How Google Works with Eric Schmidt, Jonathan Rosenberg and Marissa Mayer
14.plot: Google executives Eric Schmidt and Jonathan Rosenberg in conversation with Yahoo CEO and former Googler Marissa Mayer. This is a master class in leadership and an inside look at an iconic company.

15.title: The Art and Technology of Cirque du Soleil
15.plot: Cirque du Soleil executives Welby Altidore and Matthew Whelan reveal how technology has revolutionized the art of live performance, including enabling a holographic rendition of Michael Jackson. Moderated by Will Travis.

imdb.plot outline: "Revolutionaries" is a presentation of the Computer History Museum's lecture series from 2012-2016. The lectures feature luminaries of the tech world in engaging conversation with a wide range of interviewers. Each episode is introduced by the museum's CEO, John Hollar.
imdb.title: Revolutionaries
plot: "_Revolutionaries_ (qv)" is a presentation of the Computer History Museum's lecture series from 2012-2016. The lectures feature luminaries of the tech world in engaging conversation with a wide range of interviewers. Each episode is introduced by the museum's CEO, John Hollar.::Computer History Museum
